title: Ferenc Bene
text:
Ferenc Bene (17 December 1944 – 27 February 2006) was a Hungarian <a href="Association%20football">football</a> player of <a href="%C3%9Ajpest%20FC">Újpesti Dózsa</a>, who was a member of the team that won the gold medal at the <a href="1964%20Summer%20Olympics">1964 Summer Olympics</a> in <a href="Tokyo">Tokyo</a>, <a href="Japan">Japan</a>. A <a href="Forward%20%28association%20football%29%23Striker">striker</a>, he was the top scorer of the tournament (12 goals in 5 matches).
Bene was born in <a href="Balaton%C3%BAjlak">Balatonújlak</a>. He played his first international match against <a href="Yugoslavia%20national%20football%20team">Yugoslavia</a> on 14 October 1962, and his last against <a href="Czechoslovakia%20national%20football%20team">Czechoslovakia</a> on 12 September 1979. He obtained 76 caps and scored 36 goals. He was bronze medallist at the <a href="1964%20European%20Nations%27%20Cup">European Championship of 1964</a>, and a quarter-finalist at the <a href="1966%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">World Cup of 1966</a> (at the latter event he was the top scorer of the Hungarian national team). Bene was named Hungarian Footballer of the Year in 1964 and 1969. He died in <a href="Budapest">Budapest</a>, after a lengthy treatment following a fall at the end of 2005. His son <a href="Ferenc%20Bene%20jr.">Ferenc Bene jr.</a> is also a former player, currently working as a coach.
